questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago in spring. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Visual acuity test and slit-lamp examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin ointment may be administered in the case of bacterial conjunctivitis, which is typically unilateral and often leads to purulent discharge. Although this patient presents with conjunctivitis, his conjunctivitis is bilateral and is associated with itching and watery discharge. Moreover, it occurs during specific times of the year, which makes a bacterial infection unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir eye drops may be used to treat patients with herpes simplex conjunctivitis, which typically present with unilateral conjunctival injections, chemosis, and tearing. Concurrent vesicular blepharitis with eyelid edema is common. This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis and no evidence of eyelid involvement, making herpes simplex conjunctivitis an unlikely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Second-generation antihistamines such as ketotifen can be used in the treatment of SAC. Patients should also try to avoid irritating agents (e.g., allergens, contact lenses) if possible. The use of cold compresses, artificial tears, and local NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac) can provide additional symptomatic relief for these patients.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses may be used to treat hordeolum, which typically manifests with a painful, erythematous, pus-filled tender nodule that can perforate, releasing purulent discharge. However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with SAC, for which cold rather than warm compresses are usually recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids such as fluorometholone are used as second-line treatment for SAC. Because glucocorticoids are associated with numerous ophthalmologic side effects (e.g., intraocular pressure elevation, cataract formation), they are only indicated if patients do not respond to first-line treatment.

Glucocorticoids are also used for the treatment of uveitis, which is a common finding in patients with systemic inflammatory conditions, including ankylosing spondylitis. However, this patient's normal slit-lamp examination findings make uveitis highly unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Latanoprost eye drops are used to treat elevated intraocular pressure in chronic glaucoma, which typically affects older individuals and manifests with few, often nonspecific symptoms such as headache, burning, reddening of the eye, and possibly halos. Although this patient presents with reddening of the eyes, he is only 35 years of age and his recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy and watery conjunctivitis are more consistent with SAC.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy, watery conjunctivitis that worsen around springtime are suggestive of seasonal allergic conjunctivitis (SAC).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He says that the left eye feels “swollen,” but it does not hurt and he can still see everything clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside but had to return home today as his cousin developed an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema and a 2-mm long abrasion on his left upper eyelid. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Although episcleritis can manifest with the acute onset of bilateral ocular redness, tearing, and intact vision, eyelid edema is not consistent with this condition. Furthermore, in affected patients, hyperemia is localized to the globe and the palpebral conjunctiva appears normal; episcleral injection, not conjunctival injection, would be present.

In a minority of cases, episcleritis may be associated with underlying systemic illnesses such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which this patient has a family history. However, he has no other features of RA.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

F) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old female college student presents in the spring, reporting a 3-week history of redness, tearing, and an extreme itching sensation in both of her eyes. She had similar symptoms at the same time last year that were not as severe. She has tried placing cold compresses on her eyes and applying artificial tears, but these measures have not significantly reduced her symptoms.
When asked about possible new exposures, she reports that she has been biking to class for the past month, since the weather has gotten warm. She has not tried any new detergents, soaps, or lotions. Her medical history is significant only for eczema.
Eye examination reveals bilateral redness, conjunctival edema, and a clear watery discharge. The remainder of her physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Eye drops containing an antihistamine with mast-cell stabilizing properties

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal azelastine would be an appropriate therapy for allergic rhinitis but is unlikely to help with allergic conjunctivitis.

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by recurrent episodes of itchy, watery, red eyes after repeated exposure to outdoor allergens. Simple interventions — such as applying cool compresses and artificial tears to help dilute and remove allergens, avoiding contact lens use, keeping windows closed at home and in the car, and wearing eye protection when cycling — can all help with reduction of symptoms and avoidance of exacerbations.

This patient has already tried several general measures without success. The most appropriate next step, given the recurrence of her symptoms for more than 2 weeks, is to recommend eye drops containing an antihistamine with mast-cell stabilizing properties. Examples include olopatadine, azelastine, cetirizine, and ketotifen. These agents deliver rapid symptom relief by immediately blocking histamine receptors and also provide long-term symptom control through the mast-cell stabilizing component.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a young adult with a history of eczema who presents with recurrent episodes of allergic conjunctivitis is eye drops containing an antihistamine with mast-cell stabilizing properties.

C) INCORRECT:

Antihistamine-vasoconstrictor eye drops can be used to reduce the symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis but are appropriate only for short-term or episodic use. Regular use for longer than 2 weeks can lead to rebound redness. This patient, who has had daily symptoms for 3 weeks, requires a long-term solution.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid eye drops can have vision-threatening adverse effects (cataracts, corneal melts, increased intraocular pressure) and should therefore be used only in refractory cases that have not been responsive to other therapies. Patients who require this type of medication should be monitored closely by an ophthalmologist during treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients with allergic symptoms that are primarily ocular, medications applied directly to the eye (eye drops) are preferred over oral antihistamines because they act more quickly and are less likely to cause eye dryness.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to clinic in the spring, reporting a 3-week history of redness, tearing, and an extreme itching sensation in both of her eyes. She had similar symptoms at the same time last year that were not as severe. She has tried placing cold compresses on her eyes and applying artificial tears, but these measures have not significantly reduced her symptoms. When asked about possible new exposures, she reports that she has been playing lacrosse outside, which started at the beginning of the spring season. She has not tried any new detergents, soaps, or lotions. Her medical history is significant only for eczema.
Eye examination reveals bilateral redness, conjunctival edema, and a clear watery discharge. The remainder of her physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Topical antihistamine with mast-cell stabilizing properties

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal azelastine would be an appropriate therapy for allergic rhinitis but is unlikely to help with allergic conjunctivitis. For patients with allergic symptoms that are primarily ocular, topical medications are preferred over oral antihistamines (such as cetirizine or loratadine) because they act more quickly and are less likely to cause eye dryness.

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by recurrent episodes of itchy, watery, red eyes after repeated exposure to outdoor allergens. Simple interventions — such as applying cool compresses and artificial tears to help dilute and remove allergens, avoiding contact lens use, keeping windows closed at home and in the car, and wearing eye protection when playing sports outside — can all help with reduction of symptoms and avoidance of exacerbations. This patient has already tried several general measures without success. The most appropriate next step, given the recurrence of her symptoms for more than 2 weeks, is an antihistamine eye drop with mast-cell stabilizing properties. Examples include olopatadine, azelastine, cetirizine, and ketotifen. These agents deliver rapid symptom relief by immediately blocking histamine receptors and also provide long-term symptom control through the mast-cell stabilizing component.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a teenager with a history of eczema who presents with recurrent episodes of allergic conjunctivitis is a topical antihistamine with mast-cell stabilizing properties.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antihistamine-vasoconstrictor combinations can be used to reduce the symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis but are appropriate only for short-term or episodic use. Regular use for longer than 2 weeks can lead to rebound redness. This patient, who has had daily symptoms for 3 weeks, requires a long-term solution.

D) INCORRECT:

For patients with allergic symptoms that are primarily ocular, topical medications are preferred over oral antihistamines (such as cetirizine or loratadine) because they act more quickly and are less likely to cause eye dryness.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids can have vision-threatening adverse effects (cataracts, corneal melts, increased intraocular pressure) and should therefore be used only in refractory cases that have not been responsive to other therapies. Patients who require this type of medication should be monitored closely by an ophthalmologist during treatment.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He does not have any pain and he can see clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside. Examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

Key learning point: Allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral itchy, red eyes, watery discharge, chemosis, and eyelid edema, often triggered by environmental allergens.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

E) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-month history of dry eyes and blurred vision that worsen throughout the day. Her eyes are mildly itchy, but she has not had redness or significant pain. She feels otherwise well and has no recent history of a dry mouth or joint problems. Her medical history is notable for poorly controlled Crohn disease. She works long hours as an accountant. Physical examination reveals conjunctival injection. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Schirmer test is a rapid initial diagnostic tool for confirming keratoconjunctivitis sicca. The examiner evaluates tear production by placing a strip of filter paper in the lower eyelid and measuring the amount of tear fluid absorbed by the paper after 5 minutes. The Schirmer test should be performed before ocular surface dye staining or slit lamp examination because they can interfere with results. Additional supportive tests include tear film break-up time, tear osmolarity, and tear film analysis. Management involves identifying and addressing modifiable risk factors, using ocular lubricants, and applying artificial tears.

B) INCORRECT:

A conjunctival allergen challenge is used to identify allergens in patients with allergic conjunctivitis, which typically manifests bilaterally with dry, itchy eyes and blurred vision. However, allergic conjunctivitis most commonly occurs in individuals with a history of atopy (e.g., eczema, asthma), and this patient has no recent allergen exposure. Additionally, allergic conjunctivitis symptoms do not worsen throughout the day and instead occur acutely on exposure to the allergen. This patient has keratoconjunctivitis sicca, for which another diagnostic test is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluorescein staining is the diagnostic test of choice for keratitis and is used to identify corneal abrasions, foreign bodies in the eye, and bacterial or viral keratitis. These conditions often manifest with unilateral foreign body sensation, pain, photophobia, and/or redness, none of which are present in this patient. While fluorescein staining can detect punctate epithelial damage in advanced or refractory keratoconjunctivitis sicca, it is not the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoantibody testing (e.g., anti-Ro, anti-La) is useful for diagnosing autoimmune causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca, such as Sjogren syndrome. However, this patient does not have features of Sjogren syndrome, which include dry mouth, dry cough, and systemic symptoms (e.g., arthralgia, Raynaud phenomenon). Therefore, another diagnostic test is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Corneal culture guides targeted treatment in infectious keratitis or corneal ulcers by identifying the causative organism. These conditions typically manifest with pain, photophobia, and a foreign body sensation, none of which are present in this patient. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is a noninfectious condition, for which a different diagnostic test is indicated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with keratoconjunctivitis sicca, for which vitamin A deficiency secondary to Crohn disease is a risk factor. Prolonged screen time has most likely exacerbated her symptoms.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He reports no pain and his vision is clear. He recently spent a few days at his cousin's house in the countryside. On examination, there is bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge, chemosis, and bilateral eyelid edema. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

Key learning point: Allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral itchy, red eyes, watery discharge, chemosis, and eyelid edema, often triggered by environmental allergens.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

D) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who wears contact lenses presents with a 5-day history of unilateral eye irritation and mucoid discharge. She reports decreased tolerance for contact lens wear and blurred vision that improves with lens removal. On examination, the superior tarsal conjunctiva shows a cobblestone appearance with giant papillae formation. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Recommend discontinuation of contact lens use

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with giant papillary conjunctivitis related to contact lens use. Initial management focuses on addressing the mechanical irritation.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are not indicated for giant papillary conjunctivitis, which is a noninfectious mechanical irritation condition. The unilateral symptoms, contact lens history, and giant papillae formation suggest mechanical rather than infectious etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Conjunctival culture is unnecessary for this patient's clinical presentation. The unilateral symptoms, contact lens use history, and characteristic giant papillae formation are diagnostic for giant papillary conjunctivitis, which is a noninfectious condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate ophthalmology referral is not required for uncomplicated giant papillary conjunctivitis. Initial management involves contact lens modifications, with referral reserved for refractory disease or concerning features.

E) INCORRECT:

While topical corticosteroids may be considered for persistent symptoms, initial management involves addressing the underlying mechanical cause.
